name: Interpersonal Trust Scale
description: A 25-item measure of generalized expectancy that the word, promise, or oral or written statement of another can be relied upon. One of the earliest measures of interpersonal trust.
reference: Rotter, J. B. (1967). A new scale for the measurement of interpersonal trust. Journal of Personality, 35(4), 651-665.
instructions: Please indicate your agreement with each of the following statements using the scale provided.

questions.name: rotter_1
questions.description: Hypocrisy is on the increase in our society.

questions.name: rotter_2
questions.description: In dealing with strangers one is better off to be cautious until they have provided evidence that they are trustworthy.

questions.name: rotter_3
questions.description: This country has a dark future unless we can attract better people into politics.

questions.name: rotter_4
questions.description: Fear and social disgrace or punishment rather than conscience prevents most people from breaking the law.

questions.name: rotter_5
questions.description: Using the honor system of not having a teacher present during exams would probably result in increased cheating.

questions.name: rotter_6
questions.description: Parents usually can be relied upon to keep their promises.

questions.name: rotter_7
questions.description: The United Nations will never be an effective force in keeping world peace.

questions.name: rotter_8
questions.description: The judiciary is a place where we can all get unbiased treatment.

questions.name: rotter_9
questions.description: Most people would be horrified if they knew how much news that the public hears and sees is distorted.

questions.name: rotter_10
questions.description: It is safe to believe that in spite of what people say, most people are primarily interested in their own welfare.

questions.name: rotter_11
questions.description: Even though we have reports in newspapers, radio, and TV, it is hard to get objective accounts of public events.

questions.name: rotter_12
questions.description: The future seems very promising.

questions.name: rotter_13
questions.description: If we really knew what was going on in international politics, the public would have reason to be more frightened than they now seem to be.

questions.name: rotter_14
questions.description: Most elected public officials are really sincere in their campaign promises.

questions.name: rotter_15
questions.description: Many major national sports contests are fixed in one way or another.

questions.name: rotter_16
questions.description: Most experts can be relied upon to tell the truth about the limits of their knowledge.

questions.name: rotter_17
questions.description: Most parents can be relied upon to carry out their threats of punishment.

questions.name: rotter_18
questions.description: Most people can be counted on to do what they say they will do.

questions.name: rotter_19
questions.description: In these competitive times, one has to be alert or someone is likely to take advantage of you.

questions.name: rotter_20
questions.description: Most idealists are sincere and usually practice what they preach.

questions.name: rotter_21
questions.description: Most salespeople are honest in describing their products.

questions.name: rotter_22
questions.description: Most students in school would not cheat even if they were sure they could get away with it.

questions.name: rotter_23
questions.description: Most repair people will not overcharge people who are ignorant of their specialty.

questions.name: rotter_24
questions.description: A large share of accident claims filed against insurance companies are phony.

questions.name: rotter_25
questions.description: Most people answer public opinion polls honestly.
